spanishExample: ¡No se preocupen! Es importante, pero yo lo haré.
englishTranslation: (plural) Don't worry! It’s important, but I will do it.
vocabIncluded: "lo": "the" with no noun, as in "lo bueno"
haré: "will do/make", "I will do/make" (Hacer, future, 1st person)
preocuparse: any use of to worry with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to be worried)

spanishExample: ¿Sabes si le gusto?
englishTranslation: Do you know if she likes me?
vocabIncluded: gusto: like, I like (Gustar, present, 1st person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: ¿Te gustaría ser su amiga? Tiene siete años como tú.
englishTranslation: Would you like to be her friend? She is seven years old like you.
vocabIncluded: gustaría: would like, he/she/it would like (Gustar, conditional, 3rd person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")
tener X años: to be X years old (idiom)

spanishExample: A mi hermano le gustarían esas cosas.
englishTranslation: My brother would like those things.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
gustarían: would like, they would like (Gustar, conditional, 3rd person plural)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: A mi padre le preocupan todas esas cosas.
englishTranslation: My father worries about all those things.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
preocupan: worry, they worry (Preocupar, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: El agente es un poco viejo y no quiere dejar a la maestra.
englishTranslation: The agent is a bit old and doesn’t want to leave the teacher(f).
vocabIncluded: "the personal a": using an extra "a" before a direct object when it's a person

spanishExample: El hombre joven no tiene que preocuparse si no le gustó eso.
englishTranslation: The young man doesn’t have to worry if he didn’t like that.
vocabIncluded: gustó: liked, he/she/it liked (Gustar, preterite, 3rd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
preocuparse: any use of to worry with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to be worried)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: El jefe se ha preocupado porque le importas.
englishTranslation: The boss has worried because he cares about you.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
importas: matter, you matter (Importar, present, 2nd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
preocuparse: any use of to worry with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to be worried)

spanishExample: Eso le importaría a la reina porque no le gustan esas cosas.
englishTranslation: That would matter to the queen because she doesn't like those things.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
gustan: like, they like (Gustar, present, 3rd person plural)
importaría: would matter, he/she/it would matter (Importar, conditional, 3rd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Eso no le importará al profesor, ya ha visto cosas así.
englishTranslation: The professor won’t care, he has already seen things like that.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
al: "to the" before a masculine noun
así: adverb meaning "this way", "that way", "like this", "like that"
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
importará: will matter, he/she/it will matter (Importar, future, 3rd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: Esos doctores son geniales, nos gustaron mucho.
englishTranslation: Those doctors are great, we liked them a lot.
vocabIncluded: gustaron: liked, they liked (Gustar, preterite, 3rd person plural)
nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")

spanishExample: Estoy seguro de que a la doctora le importabas.
englishTranslation: I’m sure that the doctor(f) cared about you.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
importabas: mattered, you mattered  (Importar, imperfect, 2nd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
seguro: adjective meaning "sure" when used with Estar

spanishExample: La policía es mala, creo que no le importo a ella.
englishTranslation: The police officer(f) is bad, I think I don’t matter to her.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
creo: believe, I believe (Creer, present, 1st person)
importo: matter, I matter (Importar, present, 1st person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: La profesora está un poco vieja, ya no puede hacer eso.
englishTranslation: The professor is getting a bit old, she can’t do that anymore.
vocabIncluded: ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: Le gustaba hacer todo eso porque tenía cinco años.
englishTranslation: She liked doing all that because she was five years old.
vocabIncluded: gustaba: liked, he/she/it liked (Gustar, imperfect, 3rd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
tener X años: to be X years old (idiom)

spanishExample: Le ha gustado porque tiene siete años.
englishTranslation: She has liked it because she is seven years old.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
tener X años: to be X years old (idiom)

spanishExample: Le importaba ir contigo, pero no sé si le gustará.
englishTranslation: It was important to him to go with you, but I don’t know if he will like it.
vocabIncluded: gustará: will like, he/she/it will like (Gustar, future, 3rd person)
importaba: mattered, he/she/it mattered (Importar, imperfect, 3rd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Le importamos, pero creo que yo le importaría más.
englishTranslation: He cares about us, but I think he would care more about me.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
creo: believe, I believe (Creer, present, 1st person)
importamos: matter, we matter (Importar, present, 1st person plural)
importaría: would matter, I would matter (Importar, conditional, 1st person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Lo más importante es que le gustas.
englishTranslation: The most important thing is that she likes you.
vocabIncluded: "lo": "the" with no noun, as in "lo bueno"
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
gustas: like, you like (Gustar, present, 2nd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Lo más importante para el maestro es que ellos estén juntos.
englishTranslation: The most important (thing) for the teacher is that they be together.
vocabIncluded: "lo": "the" with no noun, as in "lo bueno"
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Me preocupo porque el presidente está loco.
englishTranslation: I worry because the president is crazy.
vocabIncluded: preocuparse: any use of to worry with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to be worried)
preocupo: worry, I worry (Preocupar, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: No creo que te importe, pero no les gustaban esas cosas.
englishTranslation: I don’t think it matters to you, but they didn’t like those things.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
creo: believe, I believe (Creer, present, 1st person)
gustaban: liked, they liked (Gustar, imperfect, 3rd person plural)
importe: matter, he/she/it matter (Importar, subjunctive, 3rd person)
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: No le gustabas al rey y eso le preocupa a la reina.
englishTranslation: The king didn’t like you and that worries the queen.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
al: "to the" before a masculine noun
gustabas: liked, you liked (Gustar, imperfect, 2nd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
preocupa: worries, he/she/it worries (Preocupar, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: No les importan las cosas que hizo el policía.
englishTranslation: The things the police officer did don't matter to them.
vocabIncluded: importan: matter, they matter (Importar, present, 3rd person plural)
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")

spanishExample: No se preocupe, me gustaría hacerlo por usted.
englishTranslation: (formal) Don’t worry, I would like to do it on your behalf.
vocabIncluded: gustaría: would like, he/she/it would like (Gustar, conditional, 3rd person)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
preocuparse: any use of to worry with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to to be worried)
usted: formal "you" after a preposition (prep. pronoun)

spanishExample: No sé si eso le va a importar a la presidenta.
englishTranslation: I don’t know if that is going to matter to the president(f).
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: No te preocupes, la jefa ya está ahí con el agente.
englishTranslation: Don’t worry, the boss (f) is already there with the agent (m).
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
ya: adverb meaning "anymore", "already", and a variety of other time-related things

spanishExample: No te tiene que gustar, pero ella es una maestra de eso.
englishTranslation: You don’t have to like it, but she is a master at that.
vocabIncluded: te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: No tienes que preocuparte, al rey le importarían esas cosas.
englishTranslation: You don’t have to worry, the king would care about those things.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
al: "to the" before a masculine noun
importarían: would matter, they would matter (Importar, conditional, 3rd person plural)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
preocuparte: to be worried (Preocupar infinitive) + CONTRACTION
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Nos importa saber si les gustamos a tus padres o no.
englishTranslation: It matters to us to know if your parents liked us or not.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
gustamos: like, we like (Gustar, present, 1st person plural)
importa: matters, he/she/it matters (Importar, present, 3rd person)
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")
nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")

spanishExample: Sé que le gustaba, no sé por qué te preocupas.
englishTranslation: I know he liked me, I don’t know what you’re worried about.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
gustaba: liked, I liked (Gustar, imperfect, 1st person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
preocupas: worry, you worry (Preocupar, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Todavía estás joven, te gusta ir a esos lugares.
englishTranslation: You’re still acting young, you like going to those places.
vocabIncluded: gusta: likes, he/she/it likes (Gustar, present, 3rd person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Todavía no soy un maestro, pero lo hago bien.
englishTranslation: I’m still not a master, but I do it fine.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
"lo": "the" with no noun, as in "lo bueno"
